EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the morning of Saturday, August 13th, a warm front lifted northward across the region. This allowed a very warm and excessively humid air mass to be in place over the area. As temperatures rose through the 80s and into the 90s, dewpoints were unusually high in the mid to upper 70s. By the afternoon hours, this produced heat index values over 100 degrees in many valley areas, with some spots in southern Litchfield County seeing heat index values over 105 degrees.||Ahead of an advancing cold front, an organized line of thunderstorms moved from west to east across all of eastern Upstate New York late in the day.   This line of thunderstorms crossed northwestern Connecticut during the late evening hours, producing damaging winds.||In addition to the gusty winds, the thunderstorms also produced a significant amount of cloud-to-ground lightning. Numerous power outages were reported throughout the region. ||Thunderstorms ended with the passage of the cold front during the overnight hours.

On the morning of Saturday, August 13th, a warm front lifted northward across the region. This allowed a very warm and excessively humid air mass to be in place over the area. As temperatures rose through the 80s and into the 90s, dewpoints were unusually high in the mid to upper 70s. By the afternoon hours, this produced heat index values over 100 degrees in many valley areas, with some spots in southern Litchfield County seeing heat index values over 105 degrees.||Ahead of an advancing cold front, an organized line of thunderstorms moved from west to east across all of eastern Upstate New York late in the day.   This line of thunderstorms crossed northwestern Connecticut during the late evening hours, producing damaging winds.||In addition to the gusty winds, the thunderstorms also produced a significant amount of cloud-to-ground lightning. Numerous power outages were reported throughout the region. ||Thunderstorms ended with the passage of the cold front during the overnight hours.

With a southerly flow in place, a warm and humid air mass continued to be in place on Sunday, August 14th.  With temperatures well into the 90s and dewpoints reaching around 70 degrees, heat index values exceeded 100 degrees during the afternoon and early evening hours across southern Litchfield County.

A very warm and humid air mass was in place over northwestern Connecticut on Friday, August 12th. Daytime temperatures were well into the 90s and dewpoints reached into the low to mid 70s. As a result, heat index values reached around 100 degrees for valley areas during the afternoon and early evening hours.

With a southerly flow in place, a warm and humid air mass continued to be in place on Sunday, August 14th.  With temperatures well into the 90s and dewpoints reaching around 70 degrees, heat index values exceeded 100 degrees during the afternoon and early evening hours across eastern Ulster and Dutchess Counties.

Rapidly developing very hot and humid weather, with daytime temperatures reaching the mid to upper 90s, brought the heat index to 100 or a little hotter during the afternoon hours of June 10th through June 12th. The heat came less than two days after a period of well below normal temperatures. Part of Interstate 90 buckled near the South Dakota border, and emergency rooms at hospitals reported that an unknown number of people suffered heat stress, heat exhaustion, or dehydration.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reaching daytime highs in the mid to upper 90s after a period of cool weather were accompanied by humid conditions, with the heat index rising to 100 degrees or a little hotter. An unknown number of people suffered from heat stress, heat exhaustion, or dehydration, as reported by hospital emergency rooms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rapidly developing very hot and humid weather, with daytime temperatures reaching the mid to upper 90s, brought the heat index to 100 or a little hotter during the afternoon hours of June 10th through June 12th. The heat came less than two days after a period of well below normal temperatures. Part of Interstate 90 buckled near the South Dakota border, and emergency rooms at hospitals reported that an unknown number of people suffered heat stress, heat exhaustion, or dehydration.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reaching daytime highs in the mid to upper 90s after a period of cool weather were accompanied by humid conditions, with the heat index rising to 100 degrees or a little hotter. An unknown number of people suffered from heat stress, heat exhaustion, or dehydration, as reported by hospital emergency rooms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rapidly developing very hot and humid weather, with daytime temperatures reaching the 95 to 100 degree range, brought the heat index to above 100 during the afternoon hours of June 10th through June 12th. The heat came less than two days after a period of well below normal temperatures. Several roads buckled in the Sioux Falls area, and emergency rooms at hospitals reported that an unknown number of people suffered heat stress, heat exhaustion, or dehydration.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reaching daytime highs of 95 to 100 after a period of cool weather were accompanied by humid conditions, with the heat index rising to a little above 100 degrees. An unknown number of people suffered from heat stress, heat exhaustion, or dehydration, as reported by hospital emergency rooms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As temperatures reached the middle to upper 90s with dew points in the middle to upper 70s, the heat index reached 110 degrees in Muscle Shoals and nearby locations during the afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index peaked at 110 degrees at 11:00 LST as the temperature hit 93 degrees combined with a dew point of 79 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Huntsville Emergency Medical Services, Inc. (HEMSI) reported to WHNT-TV that at least people suffered heat-related illnesses on the 14th in the Huntsville area.  Heat index values peaked at 99 degrees and were in the upper 90s during much of the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Huntsville Emergency Medical Services Inc. (HEMSI) reported that at least 3 people succombed to heat illness on the 14th.  Heat index values peaked at 99 degrees and was in the upper 90s for much of the afternoon hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: At 11 am CST, the heat index reached 107 degrees in Muscle Shoals. The air temperature at that time reached 92 degrees with a dew point of 78 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index in the Muscle Shoals area reached 107 degrees.  The air temperture at this time was 92 degrees with a dew point temperature of 78 degrees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index in the Muscle Shoals area reached 107 degrees.  The air temperture at this time was 92 degrees with a dew point temperature of 78 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure aloft was anchored over the south central United States during the middle of the month. This pattern resulted in temperatures in the mid 90s to near 100 across much of eastern Oklahoma. This heat combined with unseasonably high humidity resulted in afternoon heat indices in the 105 to 110 degree range. A heat-related fatality occurred in Osage County during an extended outdoor hike.

A strong ridge of high pressure aloft was anchored over the south central United States during the middle of the month. This pattern resulted in temperatures in the mid to upper 90s across west central Arkansas. This heat combined with unseasonably high humidity resulted in heat indices in the 100 to 105 degree range during the afternoons. An Army National Guard member died at Fort Chaffee, in Sebastian County, from heat-related illness on the 14th during a training exercise.

With high pressure firmly over the area, heat indices ranged from 92 to 111 degrees between the 11th and the 13th. The Emergency Medical Services Authority reported 6 calls for heat related injuries over this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat injuries inferred from number of calls to EMSA.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted through the state on the 20th, allowing southerly winds to bring about high temperatures in the low 90s along with dew points in the upper 70s to 80 at times.  As a result, heat index values easily eclipsed the 100-105 degree range and at times exceeded 110.  Additionally, overnight lows did not provide much in the way of relief with many areas seeing lows in the mid and even upper 70s at times.

Very hot and humid weather occurred across American Samoa during the second week of February.  New record high temperatures ranged from the lower to upper 90s, and heat indices were in the 112 to 118-degree range all six days near the Pago Pago International Airport. There were no medical reports on the impact of the excessive heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot and humid weather occurred across American Samoa during the second week of February. New record high temperatures ranged from the lower to upper 90s, and heat indices were in the 112 to 118-degree range all six days near the Pago Pago International Airport. There were no medical reports on the impact of the excessive heat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A southwesterly flow produced the first 90-degree temperatures of the 2016 season on the 26th.  These temperatures, in combination with high relative humidity, caused heat-related stress for more than a dozen middle school students from William Penn Middle School in Lower Makefield Township (Bucks County PA) while they were attending a Trenton Thunder baseball game at Arm and Hammer Park in Trenton.  Many of these students started felling light-headed at the stadium, and were taken to a nearby hospital for treatment for heat stroke. Other students were treated after they returned to their school during the early afternoon hours.  The high temperature at Trenton on the 26th was 90 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A southwesterly flow produced the first 90-degree temperatures of the 2016 season on the 26th. These temperatures, in combination with high relative humidity, caused heat-related stress for more than a dozen middle school students from William Penn Middle School in Lower Makefield Township (Bucks County PA) while they were attending a Trenton Thunder baseball game at Arm and Hammer Park in Trenton. Many of these students started felling light-headed at the stadium, and were taken to a nearby hospital for treatment for heat stroke. Other students were treated after they returned to their school during the early afternoon hours. The high temperature at Trenton on the 26th was 90 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During a period of unseasonably warm weather, 17-year-old Jeramiah Smith swimming across the Green River in Auburn with six friends had trouble and then went under in the cold river water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During a period of unseasonably warm weather with Puget Sound area temperatures near 90 degrees, officials say 17-year-old Jeramiah Smith was swimming across the Green River in Auburn with six friends about 7:30 p.m. when he started having trouble about halfway through.  Smiths friends said they saw him travel downstream and then go under water. River temperatures were near 50 degrees and cold water immersion was thought to be the cause of the youth's trouble in the water.

An early-season push of tropical heat and humidity resulted in potentially hazardous heat indices. The hazardous heat indices were south of a stationary front that was draped along the Interstate 64 corridor. Maximum heat indices were generally from 105 to 110 degrees. Actual air temperatures reached 97 at Carbondale and 100 at Paducah, Kentucky. The high of 100 degrees at Paducah, KY was the third earliest in the season for a 100-degree temperature. The only earlier occurrences were on June 14, 1987 and June 14, 1943. In those years in which it occurred, the average date of the first 100-degree temperature has been July 17 at Paducah.

South of a stationary front draped across central Indiana and Illinois, potentially hazardous heat and humidity was observed over western Kentucky. Afternoon heat indices peaked between 105 and 110 degrees. At the Paducah airport, the highest hourly heat index reading was 109 degrees. Other maximum hourly heat index readings included 105 at Henderson, 108 at Madisonville, 107 at Murray, and 106 at Hopkinsville. The low temperature of 81 degrees at Paducah was the warmest low temperature on record for the month of June.

Unseasonably strong ridge of high pressure resulted in a period of early-season hot temperatures across Northwest Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures of 95 to 100 in early June lead to people seeking relief at local rivers. One drowning was reported east of Springfield during this hot spell.

Strong high pressure brought record tying and record breaking heat to northern Arizona over the first weekend in June.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high of 87 degrees was set at the Flagstaff airport. The previous record was 86 set for this date was 86 set in 1996.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple days of temperatures climbing into the upper 90s with heat indices around 105 led to heat related illnesses and the first heat related death of the year in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Mesquite emergency dispatcher was able to use new location technology to help save the life of a 14 year old boy who called and could not be verbally understood due to heat complications. The boy was treated and released from the hospital.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple days of temperatures climbing into the upper 90s with heat indices around 105 led to heat related illnesses and the first heat related death of the year in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One person died due to heat related complications, according to the Dallas County medical examiner's office. This was the first heat-related death of the year in Dallas County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple days of temperatures climbing into the upper 90s with heat indices around 105 led to heat related illnesses and the first heat related death of the year in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven people were treated for heat exhaustion outside of Gilley's in Dallas shortly after the Donald Trump rally. One person had to be transported for treatment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple days of temperatures climbing into the upper 90s with heat indices around 105 led to heat related illnesses and the first heat related death of the year in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A six-month old girl died after being left in a hot car in Melissa, TX.

Very strong high pressure developed in the upper atmosphere across the desert southwest during the middle of June, beginning on Saturday, June 18th and continuing into the middle of the following week. The very warm temperatures aloft, combined with dry air and sunny skies allowed high temperatures to climb to dangerous levels across the lower deserts each day. Desert high temperatures on Saturday reached or exceeded 110 degrees in many locations and by Sunday, many hotter deserts ranged between 115 and 120 degrees. An Excessive Heat Warning was issued for all of the lower Arizona deserts, starting 1000MST Sunday and continuing through the middle of the following week. The dangerous heat led to the deaths of multiple people, including a mountain biker in the greater Phoenix area during the morning hours on Sunday, June 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Unusually strong high pressure aloft developed across Arizona during the middle of June, beginning Saturday June 18th and persisting into next week. The strong high pressure, combined with dry air and sunny skies, led to very dangerous heat across the greater Phoenix area on Sunday June 19th. An Excessive Heat Warning was in effect starting at 1000MST and continuing through the evening hours; the high temperature in Phoenix reached 118 degrees which set a new record for the date. This dangerous heat led to the death of a mountain biker in the Phoenix Mountain Preserve during the morning hours. According to spokesman Captain Larry Subervi of the Phoenix Fire Department, fire crews responded to reports of an adult with heat related issues about 1 mile from the Desert Vista Trailhead shortly before 0900MST. This was in the area near Interstate 17 and Jomax Road. The 28 year old woman, a personal trainer, had set out biking on the trail with two friends at about 0600MST and they all had water. Shortly before 0900MST, her friends - who are doctors - started CPR and called 911. She soon stopped breathing. Crews reached the woman about 0930MST and continued to provide aid while airlifting her to the parking lot where an ambulance awaited. According to Captain Subervi, she was transported to a local emergency room in extremely critical condition and she lost her pulse due to the exhaustion. He indicated that there were no other injuries and her condition was 100 percent heat-related illness. The woman, who was an experience biker, became tired in the heat and told her friends that she could not continue before gaining an altered mental status. Tom Grace, a technician on the helicopter that airlifted her off the trail, said that the operation was one of the riskiest types of rescues performed by the department due to the heat and the location of the woman.

A sagging cold front in central and southern Minnesota initiated a number of storms on the afternoon of the 10th.  While the boundary did not continue its march southward into Iowa, the storms continued to progress southeastward, eventually entering Iowa.  As a result, the storms produced heavy rainfall along with a handful of hail and wind reports.  On the afternoon of the 11th, the cold front sagged down into northern Iowa and initiated a couple of storms that produced an instance of damaging winds. In addition to the storms, a death of an infant occurred from the heat by being left in an unattended vehicle on the afternoon of the 11th in Polk County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 6 month old boy was left in an attended vehicle outside a business while the father was inside the business. The high at KDSM was 91 degrees that afternoon with the highest heat index of 97.

A warm and humid day unfolded across central Illinois on June 14th, with afternoon high temperatures topping out around 90 degrees and heat index values approaching 100. Ten people were overcome by heat while attending a gathering outside the state capital in Springfield.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten people were overcome by heat while attending a gathering outside the state capital in Springfield.  Four of them were transported to the hospital.  The temperature at the time of the event was 89 degrees and the heat index was 98.

An early-season push of tropical heat and humidity resulted in potentially hazardous heat indices. The hazardous heat indices were south of a stationary front that was draped across southwest Indiana and southern Illinois. Maximum heat indices were generally from 105 to 110 degrees. The actual air temperature reached 100 at Paducah, Kentucky. The high of 100 degrees at Paducah, KY was the third earliest in the season for a 100-degree temperature. The only earlier occurrences were on June 14, 1987 and June 14, 1943. In those years in which it occurred, the average date of the first 100-degree temperature has been July 17 at Paducah.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: South of a stationary front draped across central Indiana and Illinois, potentially hazardous heat and humidity was observed over western Kentucky. Afternoon heat indices peaked between 105 and 110 degrees. At the Paducah airport, the highest hourly heat index reading was 109 degrees. Other maximum hourly heat index readings included 105 at Henderson, 108 at Madisonville, 107 at Murray, and 106 at Hopkinsville. The low temperature of 81 degrees at Paducah was the warmest low temperature on record for the month of June.

Afternoon heat indices peaked between 105 and 110 degrees. At the Paducah airport, the highest hourly heat index reading was 109 degrees. Other maximum hourly heat index readings included 105 at Henderson, 108 at Madisonville, 107 at Murray, and 106 at Hopkinsville. The low temperature of 81 degrees at Paducah was the warmest low temperature on record for the month of June.

An early-season push of tropical heat and humidity resulted in potentially hazardous heat indices. The hazardous heat indices were south of a stationary front that was draped across southwest Indiana and southern Illinois. Maximum heat indices were generally from 105 to 110 degrees. The actual air temperature reached 100 at Paducah, Kentucky. The high of 100 degrees at Paducah, KY was the third earliest in the season for a 100-degree temperature. The only earlier occurrences were on June 14, 1987 and June 14, 1943. In those years in which it occurred, the average date of the first 100-degree temperature has been July 17 at Paducah.

Excessive Heat gripped the area July 18th - July 24th. High temperatures ranged from the middle to upper 90s with the Heat Index up to 110 degrees. The St. Louis County Health Department reported 1 death and 70 injuries.

Very strong high pressure developed in the upper atmosphere across the desert southwest during the middle of June, beginning on Saturday, June 18th and continuing into the middle of the following week. The very warm temperatures aloft, combined with dry air and sunny skies allowed high temperatures to climb to dangerous levels across the lower deserts each day. Desert high temperatures on Saturday reached or exceeded 110 degrees in many locations and by Sunday, many hotter deserts ranged between 115 and 120 degrees. An Excessive Heat Warning was issued for all of the lower Arizona deserts, starting 1000MST Sunday and continuing through the middle of the following week. The dangerous heat led to the deaths of multiple people, including a mountain biker in the greater Phoenix area during the morning hours on Sunday, June 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very strong high pressure aloft developed across Arizona during the middle of June 2016, beginning on Saturday June 18th and persisting into early next week. In combination with dry air and sunny skies, the strong high pressure led to the development of dangerous heat across the lower central deserts. The high temperature for the day was 111 at Phoenix and although an Excessive Heat Warning was not yet in effect, heat impact level data suggested that borderline warning conditions had already developed across the greater Phoenix area and northern Pinal county. According to the Pinal County Sheriff's Office, a 25 year old man died while hiking on the Peralta Trail in Gold Canyon during the afternoon hours on June 18th. The victim died as a result of exposure to extreme heat; search and rescue teams were called out to the trail just after 1330MST. According to the Sheriff's Office, a friend told deputies that the victim started hiking at 0730MST for what was to be a day hike; unfortunately he ran out of water after just a few hours. Shortly thereafter he exhibited signs of heat illness and the friend called 911 for help. The man's condition continued to get worse, he lost consciousness and never recovered. This was just one of three heat-related emergency calls within a four hour period on Saturday in the Superstition wilderness. The other two victims ended up with just minor heat-related injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heat wave occurred across the region with afternoon highs in the mid 90's and overnight lows staying above 70. The prolonged nature of the heat unfortunately resulted in three deaths in the city of Philadelphia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three people died from exposure to prolonged heat in the city of Philadelphia. One person was in Northeast Philadelphia the second in Fox Chase and the third in Grays Ferry.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One person died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One person died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure aloft was anchored over the south central United States during the middle of the month. This pattern resulted in temperatures in the mid 90s to near 100 across much of eastern Oklahoma. This heat combined with unseasonably high humidity resulted in heat indices in the 110 to 115 degree range during the afternoons of the 15th through the 17th. Two heat-related fatalities occurred in Tulsa County during this period.  One of the fatalities was the result of a man doing roofing work, and the other was a woman who was found dead in her home with no air conditioning. During this period, at least 29 other people were treated for heat-related illness in Tulsa County that required medical assistance.

Intense high pressure over the southwest U.S. led to record-breaking temperatures of 108 to 114 degrees in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona. No heat-related fatalities occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures over a four-day stretch contributed to at least 14 serious heat-related illnesses in Eastern Pima County alone.  A 72-year old man was airlifted to the hospital after he suffered heat exhaustion on Tanque Verde Falls hiking trail on June 3rd. Tucson International Airport tied a record high of 107 degrees on June 3rd, and set new records of 110 on June 5th and 111 on June 6th, respectively.  Organ Pipe National Monument set new record highs of 111 on June 3rd and 114 on June 5th. Temperatures during the period were as hot as 108 in Oracle and Sasabe, 109 in the Sierra Vista/Benson area and 112 in Sells.

Intense high pressure over the southwest U.S. led to record-breaking high temperatures of 108 to 119 degrees and resulted in four fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A three-day stretch of very hot temperatures resulted in four heat-related fatalities and at least 19 heat-related illnesses in southeast Arizona, all of which were reported in Eastern Pima County. Out of three men who were hiking the Ventana Canyon Trail Sunday, June 19th, two died of heat stroke, although one was not found until Tuesday. The third man suffered heat-related injuries but survived. A woman died of heat stoke that same day hiking Finger Rock Trail. Her companion was airlifted to a hospital for treatment of heat-related illness. Also on that same day, a woman walking the city's Loop walking and biking trail succumbed to heat stroke near Interstate 10 and Irvington. Tucson International Airport recorded its third hottest day ever and the warmest day since 1994 with a record setting 115 degrees on June 19th. Other record highs on the 19th included 115 degrees at Picacho Peak, 119 at Organ Pipe National Monument, 112 at Safford and 109 at Nogales and Bisbee-Douglas Airport. On June 20th, additional record highs were set although the actual temperatures were not quite as hot.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large dome of high pressure that was centered across the mid section of the nation the week of July 18th, caused temperatures to rise into the 80s and 90s across the state. These temperatures combined with very high dew points in the mid to upper 70s, created heat indices between 100-115 degrees during the afternoon of Wednesday, July 20th, and into Friday afternoon, July 22nd over portions of central and southern Minnesota. ||The highest heat indices were initially across west central and into parts of east central Minnesota on Wednesday, July 20th. This is where a frontal boundary allowed for dew points to pool and led to heat indices above 105 degrees for several hours. ||As the front sagged southward, the pooled dew points and associated higher heat indices also sagged southward across southern Minnesota. Along the Iowa border, initially heat indices were much lower on Wednesday, but by Friday, these heat indices rose above 105 degrees as the front sagged to the south. ||The highest heat indices occurred between 12 noon and 7 pm. However, even the overnight temperatures only fell into the upper 70s to lower 80s, creating dangerous readings for those who did not have air conditioning or were caught out in the elements. ||The following are recorded highest heat indices in this three day period;||Near Savage 120 F  |Near Eagan 118 F|Near Lake City 118 F |Faribault 117 F |Near Bloomington 117 F |New Prague 116 F |Near Inver Grove Heights 116 F  |East of Jordan 116 F |St. Paul 116 F |Farmington 115 F  |Redwood Falls 115 F|Madelia  114 F|South of Red Wing 114 F|Minnesota Lake 114 F |Morton 114 F|Lakeville 113 F|Morristown 113 F|West of Clara City 113 F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several surface observations across Freeborn County measured heat indices over 105 degrees for several hours during the afternoon of Friday, July 22nd. The highest heat indices that was measured was 109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure aloft was anchored over the south central United States during the middle of the month. This pattern resulted in temperatures in the mid 90s to near 100 across much of eastern Oklahoma. This heat combined with unseasonably high humidity resulted in heat indices in the 105 to 110 degree range during the afternoons of the 17th and 18th. A heat-related fatality occurred in Delaware County as a woman died in her home with no air conditioning. Another heat-related fatality occurred in Tulsa County as a man was found dead in his home with no air conditioning. At least eight people were also treated for heat-related illness by medical personnel in Tulsa County.

A strong ridge of high pressure aloft was anchored over the south central United States during the middle of the month. This pattern resulted in temperatures in the mid 90s to near 100 across much of eastern Oklahoma. This heat combined with unseasonably high humidity resulted in heat indices in the 110 to 115 degree range during the afternoons of the 15th through the 17th. Two heat-related fatalities occurred in Tulsa County during this period.  One of the fatalities was the result of a man doing roofing work, and the other was a woman who was found dead in her home with no air conditioning. During this period, at least 29 other people were treated for heat-related illness in Tulsa County that required medical assistance.
Intense high pressure over the southwest U.S. led to record-breaking high temperatures of 108 to 119 degrees and resulted in four fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A three-day stretch of very hot temperatures resulted in four heat-related fatalities and at least 19 heat-related illnesses in southeast Arizona, all of which were reported in Eastern Pima County. Out of three men who were hiking the Ventana Canyon Trail Sunday, June 19th, two died of heat stroke, although one was not found until Tuesday. The third man suffered heat-related injuries but survived. A woman died of heat stoke that same day hiking Finger Rock Trail. Her companion was airlifted to a hospital for treatment of heat-related illness. Also on that same day, a woman walking the city's Loop walking and biking trail succumbed to heat stroke near Interstate 10 and Irvington. Tucson International Airport recorded its third hottest day ever and the warmest day since 1994 with a record setting 115 degrees on June 19th. Other record highs on the 19th included 115 degrees at Picacho Peak, 119 at Organ Pipe National Monument, 112 at Safford and 109 at Nogales and Bisbee-Douglas Airport. On June 20th, additional record highs were set although the actual temperatures were not quite as hot.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One person suffered heat stroke in Death Valley on June 1st (she survived), and another person was found dead, presumably from the heat, on June 9th. High temperatures at Furnace Creek during this period ranged from 115F to 120F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two people were stranded in the park when their car became stuck in loose sand. They walked for two miles before being found. One of them, described as an older woman, suffered from heat stroke. She recovered after a week in the hospital.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One person suffered heat stroke in Death Valley on June 1st (she survived), and another person was found dead, presumably from the heat, on June 9th. High temperatures at Furnace Creek during this period ranged from 115F to 120F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two park visitors found a dead motorcyclist on Harry Wade Road in the extreme southern end of the park June 9th. It is unknown when the man died.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures in Las Vegas reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria on five out of the six days. There were nine direct fatalities and one indirect fatality between the 3rd and the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures in Las Vegas ranged from 105F to 109F for six days, with five of the six reaching 107F or higher. The excessive heat caused or contributed to ten deaths.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures in Las Vegas reached Excessive Heat Warning criteria from the 19th through the 21st, and remained just below those levels through the 29th. There were nine direct and eight indirect fatalities between June 20th and 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached Excessive Heat Warning levels June 19th through the 21st, and then persisted just below those levels through the 29th. The heat caused or contributed to nine direct and eight indirect fatalities from the 20th through the 29th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge and offshore flow brought very hot temperatures and low relative humidity to areas west of the mountains. Temperatures ranged from 85 along the coast to 105 degrees in the San Diego County valleys and Inland Empire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A survey of 19 local hospitals indicated 20 heat related 911 calls over two days, with 3 heat related injuries and 1 death. These numbers do not include urgent care facilities and are therefore likely underdone.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: It does not take dangerous or excessive levels of heat during the summer in southern Arizona to cause serious, even fatal, repercussions to the populace of Phoenix. Friday September 9th was a normal summer day in September; the high in Phoenix was 103 degrees and that is just 1 degree above the seasonal normal for the date. Despite the near normal nature of the heat, a man visiting from Switzerland went hiking in the afternoon and he was overcome by the heat, eventually passing away. Fire crews performed CPR on him to no avail. Triple digit heat can be very dangerous, especially to someone who is not used to the heat and who does not take the proper precautions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Near normal summer heat occurred in the greater Phoenix metropolitan area on September 9th, the high in Phoenix was 103 compared to the normal of 102. Despite the near-normal nature of the heat, a man from Switzerland who was not used to triple digit heat died while hiking Camelback Mountain in Phoenix during the afternoon. The story was reported on the ABC15 website. According to the Phoenix Fire Department, the man had been hiking Camelback Mountain in the afternoon with 3 friends before he became separated from the group. He was heard yelling for help by employees of the Phoenician Resort who then went to meet him. The man was nearly on resort property when he began behaving erratically and then stopped breathing. Fire crews soon arrived and began performing CPR while on the way to the Phoenix hospital; at the hospital he was pronounced dead.

CZ_NAME: LAKE MEAD/LAKE MOHAVE NATIONAL RECREATION AREA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The warmest day of the year so far led to a possible heat exhaustion case.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An unresponsive hiker was airlifted from the Gold Strike Trail Head with suspected heat exhaustion. Temperatures were in the lower to mid 90s at the time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One man died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One man died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures soared into the mid 90's across Delaware. This was coupled with a considerable amount of outdoor activities going on including several high school football games. 12 players cramped up during the Carvel @ Concord game. Five people at White Clay Creek State park suffered from heat exhaustion with four more occurrences in Baynard stadium.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nine direct injuries (heat exhaustion) and twelve indirect injuries ( cramps during football).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure aloft set up across the Southern Plains and Lower Mississippi Valley resulting in hot daytime temperatures in the mid 90s to near 100 degrees. Dewpoint temperatures were in the middle 70s to upper 70s across the region as well...resulting in late morning and afternoon heat index values near or above 105 degrees.

High pressure over the western Atlantic Ocean ushered in hot and humid air northward across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of hot temperatures in the 90s, and high humidity resulted in a heat index up to 110 degrees at Montgomery Airport. In addition, a heat index of 109 was observed at nearby Poughkeepsie.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large dome of high pressure that was centered across the mid section of the nation the week of July 18th, caused temperatures to rise into the 80s and 90s across the state. These temperatures combined with very high dew points in the mid to upper 70s, created heat indices between 100-115 degrees during the afternoon of Wednesday, July 20th, and into Friday afternoon, July 22nd over portions of central and southern Minnesota. ||The highest heat indices were initially across west central and into parts of east central Minnesota on Wednesday, July 20th. This is where a frontal boundary allowed for dew points to pool and led to heat indices above 105 degrees for several hours. ||As the front sagged southward, the pooled dew points and associated higher heat indices also sagged southward across southern Minnesota. Along the Iowa border, initially heat indices were much lower on Wednesday, but by Friday, these heat indices rose above 105 degrees as the front sagged to the south. ||The highest heat indices occurred between 12 noon and 7 pm. However, even the overnight temperatures only fell into the upper 70s to lower 80s, creating dangerous readings for those who did not have air conditioning or were caught out in the elements. ||The following are recorded highest heat indices in this three day period;||Near Savage 120 F  |Near Eagan 118 F|Near Lake City 118 F |Faribault 117 F |Near Bloomington 117 F |New Prague 116 F |Near Inver Grove Heights 116 F  |East of Jordan 116 F |St. Paul 116 F |Farmington 115 F  |Redwood Falls 115 F|Madelia  114 F|South of Red Wing 114 F|Minnesota Lake 114 F |Morton 114 F|Lakeville 113 F|Morristown 113 F|West of Clara City 113 F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several surface observations across Anoka County measured heat indices over 105 degrees for several hours during the afternoon of Wednesday, July 20th, and again Thursday afternoon July 21st. Temperatures only managed to fall into the mid to upper 70s during the morning of July 21st, and rebounded into the 80s and 90s once again by the afternoon. The highest heat index was 115 degrees.

Afternoon heat indices peaked from 105 to 114 degrees across western Kentucky. Specific peak heat index readings included 113 degrees at Paducah, 112 at Owensboro, and 109 degrees at Madisonville and Hopkinsville. Actual air temperatures reached the lower to mid 90's. Hot and very humid air built up under a subtropical 500 mb ridge that was centered over the southern states and extended north through the mid Mississippi Valley.

A large dome of high pressure that was centered across the mid section of the nation the week of July 18th, caused temperatures to rise into the 80s and 90s across the state. These temperatures combined with very high dew points in the mid to upper 70s, created heat indices between 100-115 degrees during the afternoon of Wednesday, July 20th, and into Friday afternoon, July 22nd over portions of central and southern Minnesota. ||The highest heat indices were initially across west central and into parts of east central Minnesota on Wednesday, July 20th. This is where a frontal boundary allowed for dew points to pool and led to heat indices above 105 degrees for several hours. ||As the front sagged southward, the pooled dew points and associated higher heat indices also sagged southward across southern Minnesota. Along the Iowa border, initially heat indices were much lower on Wednesday, but by Friday, these heat indices rose above 105 degrees as the front sagged to the south. ||The highest heat indices occurred between 12 noon and 7 pm. However, even the overnight temperatures only fell into the upper 70s to lower 80s, creating dangerous readings for those who did not have air conditioning or were caught out in the elements. ||The following are recorded highest heat indices in this three day period;||Near Savage 120 F  |Near Eagan 118 F|Near Lake City 118 F |Faribault 117 F |Near Bloomington 117 F |New Prague 116 F |Near Inver Grove Heights 116 F  |East of Jordan 116 F |St. Paul 116 F |Farmington 115 F  |Redwood Falls 115 F|Madelia  114 F|South of Red Wing 114 F|Minnesota Lake 114 F |Morton 114 F|Lakeville 113 F|Morristown 113 F|West of Clara City 113 F.

Temperatures only managed to fall into the mid to upper 70s during the morning of July 21st, and rebounded into the 80s and 90s once again by the afternoon. The highest heat index value was 110 degrees.

Ridge of high pressure brought excessively hot temperatures to Southwest Washington.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures around 100 degrees lead to people seeking relief at local rivers. One drowning was reported at Paradise Point State Park west of La Center during this hot spell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ridge of high pressure and offshore winds brought temperatures along the North Oregon Coast up into the mid 80s to mid 90s on August 25. Inland, temperatures on August 25-26 reached the upper 90s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures in the mid 80s to mid 90s lead to people seeking relief at local rivers, lakes, and beaches. One swimmer drowned at Siltcoos Lake south of Florence during this event.

Strong high pressure settled over South Central Texas bringing hot and humid weather. A local TV station reported a seven month old baby was found dead in a hot car in Helotes. The story said the boy's father forgot to drop him off at daycare. The boy was found at 3:09 PM. The heat index reached 109 at San Antonio International Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure settled over South Central Texas bringing hot and humid weather. A local TV station reported a seven month old baby was found dead in a hot car in Helotes. The story said the boy's father forgot to drop him off at daycare. The boy was found at 3:09 PM. The heat index reached 109 at San Antonio International Airport.

These temperatures combined with very high dew points in the mid to upper 70s, created heat indices between 100-115 degrees during the afternoon of Wednesday, July 20th, and into Friday afternoon, July 22nd over portions of central and southern Minnesota. ||The highest heat indices were initially across west central and into parts of east central Minnesota on Wednesday, July 20th. This is where a frontal boundary allowed for dew points to pool and led to heat indices above 105 degrees for several hours. ||As the front sagged southward, the pooled dew points and associated higher heat indices also sagged southward across southern Minnesota. Along the Iowa border, initially heat indices were much lower on Wednesday, but by Friday, these heat indices rose above 105 degrees as the front sagged to the south. ||The highest heat indices occurred between 12 noon and 7 pm. However, even the overnight temperatures only fell into the upper 70s to lower 80s, creating dangerous readings for those who did not have air conditioning or were caught out in the elements. ||The following are recorded highest heat indices in this three day period;||Near Savage 120 F  |Near Eagan 118 F|Near Lake City 118 F |Faribault 117 F |Near Bloomington 117 F |New Prague 116 F |Near Inver Grove Heights 116 F  |East of Jordan 116 F |St. Paul 116 F |Farmington 115 F  |Redwood Falls 115 F|Madelia  114 F|South of Red Wing 114 F|Minnesota Lake 114 F |Morton 114 F|Lakeville 113 F|Morristown 113 F|West of Clara City 113 F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several surface observations across Sherburne County measured heat indices over 105 degrees for several hours during the afternoon of Wednesday, July 20th. The highest heat indices that was measured was 111 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure aloft set up across the Southern Plains and Lower Mississippi Valley resulting in hot daytime temperatures in the mid 90s to near 100 degrees. Dewpoint temperatures were in the middle 70s to upper 70s across the region as well...resulting in late morning and afternoon heat index values near or above 105 degrees.

Ridge of high pressure and offshore winds brought temperatures along the North Oregon Coast up into the mid 80s to mid 90s on August 25. Inland, temperatures on August 25-26 reached the upper 90s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: News reported 8 runners were taken to the hospital with heat-related injuries during the Hood-to-Coast relay through Portland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon heat indices peaked from 105 to 114 degrees across western Kentucky. Specific peak heat index readings included 113 degrees at Paducah, 112 at Owensboro, and 109 degrees at Madisonville and Hopkinsville. Actual air temperatures reached the lower to mid 90's. Hot and very humid air built up under a subtropical 500 mb ridge that was centered over the southern states and extended north through the mid Mississippi Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several surface observations across Blue Earth County measured heat indices over 105 degrees for several hours during the afternoon of Wednesday, July 20th, and again Thursday afternoon July 21st. Temperatures only managed to fall into the mid to upper 70s during the morning of July 21st, and rebounded into the 80s and 90s once again by the afternoon. The highest heat index was 114 degrees.

South of the Interstate 64 corridor, afternoon heat indices peaked from 105 to 114 degrees on the afternoons of the 4th and 5th. In Benton in Franklin County, a 43-year-old man died after working outdoors in the heat. The man was found unresponsive indoors, and he was pronounced dead that evening at a local hospital. The coroner reported evidence of a heat stroke. The highest heat indices occurred on the afternoon of the 5th, when the heat index peaked at 114 degrees at Metropolis, 112 at Cairo, and 107 at Harrisburg. Actual air temperatures reached the lower to mid 90's. Hot and very humid air built up under a subtropical 500 mb ridge that was centered over the southern states and extended north through the mid Mississippi Valley.

A prolonged heat wave impacted southeastern Pennsylvania from 10-16 August with afternoon temperatures in the low-mid 90s and overnight lows in the mid to upper 70s. When factoring in oppressive humidity with dewpoints in the upper 70s, maximum heat indices exceeded 100 degrees most afternoons. The peak of the high heat/humidity occurred on 14 August with maximum heat index values ranging from 105 to 110 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum heat index values reached 105 to 110 degrees during the afternoon and early evening.

A period of very hot and humid conditions occurred with highs each day into 90's. The cumulative effect of the heat resulted in some heat related deaths and injuries. Brownouts occurred across the region and nine residents in Prospect Park (Delaware County) had to be evacuated due to the loss of electricity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five heat related deaths were confirmed. All of the individuals had medical conditions which also were contributing factors.

A strong ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere over the south central and southeastern United States resulted in unseasonably hot weather across eastern Oklahoma during the middle of August. Afternoon temperatures in the upper 90s to near 100 prevailed across much of the area. This heat, combined with very humid conditions, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range during the afternoons of August 10th and 11th.

South of the Interstate 64 corridor, afternoon heat indices peaked from 105 to 114 degrees on the afternoons of the 4th and 5th. In Benton in Franklin County, a 43-year-old man died after working outdoors in the heat. The man was found unresponsive indoors, and he was pronounced dead that evening at a local hospital. The coroner reported evidence of a heat stroke. The highest heat indices occurred on the afternoon of the 5th, when the heat index peaked at 114 degrees at Metropolis, 112 at Cairo, and 107 at Harrisburg. Actual air temperatures reached the lower to mid 90's. Hot and very humid air built up under a subtropical 500 mb ridge that was centered over the southern states and extended north through the mid Mississippi Valley.

A large dome of high pressure that was centered across the mid section of the nation the week of July 18th, caused temperatures to rise into the 80s and 90s across the state. These temperatures combined with very high dew points in the mid to upper 70s, created heat indices between 100-115 degrees during the afternoon of Wednesday, July 20th, and into Friday afternoon, July 22nd over portions of central and southern Minnesota. ||The highest heat indices were initially across west central and into parts of east central Minnesota on Wednesday, July 20th. This is where a frontal boundary allowed for dew points to pool and led to heat indices above 105 degrees for several hours. ||As the front sagged southward, the pooled dew points and associated higher heat indices also sagged southward across southern Minnesota. Along the Iowa border, initially heat indices were much lower on Wednesday, but by Friday, these heat indices rose above 105 degrees as the front sagged to the south. ||The highest heat indices occurred between 12 noon and 7 pm. However, even the overnight temperatures only fell into the upper 70s to lower 80s, creating dangerous readings for those who did not have air conditioning or were caught out in the elements. ||The following are recorded highest heat indices in this three day period;||Near Savage 120 F  |Near Eagan 118 F|Near Lake City 118 F |Faribault 117 F |Near Bloomington 117 F |New Prague 116 F |Near Inver Grove Heights 116 F  |East of Jordan 116 F |St. Paul 116 F |Farmington 115 F  |Redwood Falls 115 F|Madelia  114 F|South of Red Wing 114 F|Minnesota Lake 114 F |Morton 114 F|Lakeville 113 F|Morristown 113 F|West of Clara City 113 F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several surface observations across Faribault County measured heat indices over 105 degrees for several hours during the afternoon of Friday, July 22nd. The highest heat indices that was measured was 108 degrees.

A strong ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere over the south central and southeastern United States resulted in unseasonably hot weather across eastern Oklahoma during the middle of August. Afternoon temperatures in the upper 90s to near 100 prevailed across much of the area. This heat, combined with very humid conditions, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range during the afternoons of August 10th and 11th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large dome of high pressure that was centered across the mid section of the nation the week of July 18th, caused temperatures to rise into the 80s and 90s across the state. These temperatures combined with very high dew points in the mid to upper 70s, created heat indices between 100-115 degrees during the afternoon of Wednesday, July 20th, and into Friday afternoon, July 22nd over portions of central and southern Minnesota. ||The highest heat indices were initially across west central and into parts of east central Minnesota on Wednesday, July 20th. This is where a frontal boundary allowed for dew points to pool and led to heat indices above 105 degrees for several hours. ||As the front sagged southward, the pooled dew points and associated higher heat indices also sagged southward across southern Minnesota. Along the Iowa border, initially heat indices were much lower on Wednesday, but by Friday, these heat indices rose above 105 degrees as the front sagged to the south. ||The highest heat indices occurred between 12 noon and 7 pm. However, even the overnight temperatures only fell into the upper 70s to lower 80s, creating dangerous readings for those who did not have air conditioning or were caught out in the elements. ||The following are recorded highest heat indices in this three day period;||Near Savage 120 F  |Near Eagan 118 F|Near Lake City 118 F |Faribault 117 F |Near Bloomington 117 F |New Prague 116 F |Near Inver Grove Heights 116 F  |East of Jordan 116 F |St. Paul 116 F |Farmington 115 F  |Redwood Falls 115 F|Madelia  114 F|South of Red Wing 114 F|Minnesota Lake 114 F |Morton 114 F|Lakeville 113 F|Morristown 113 F|West of Clara City 113 F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several surface observations across Waseca County measured heat indices over 105 degrees for several hours during the afternoon of Thursday, July 21th, and again Friday afternoon July 22nd. Temperatures only managed to fall into the mid to upper 70s during the morning of July 22nd, and rebounded into the 80s and 90s once again by the afternoon. The highest heat index value was 112 degrees.

These temperatures combined with very high dew points in the mid to upper 70s, created heat indices between 100-115 degrees during the afternoon of Wednesday, July 20th, and into Friday afternoon, July 22nd over portions of central and southern Minnesota. ||The highest heat indices were initially across west central and into parts of east central Minnesota on Wednesday, July 20th. This is where a frontal boundary allowed for dew points to pool and led to heat indices above 105 degrees for several hours. ||As the front sagged southward, the pooled dew points and associated higher heat indices also sagged southward across southern Minnesota. Along the Iowa border, initially heat indices were much lower on Wednesday, but by Friday, these heat indices rose above 105 degrees as the front sagged to the south. ||The highest heat indices occurred between 12 noon and 7 pm. However, even the overnight temperatures only fell into the upper 70s to lower 80s, creating dangerous readings for those who did not have air conditioning or were caught out in the elements. ||The following are recorded highest heat indices in this three day period;||Near Savage 120 F  |Near Eagan 118 F|Near Lake City 118 F |Faribault 117 F |Near Bloomington 117 F |New Prague 116 F |Near Inver Grove Heights 116 F  |East of Jordan 116 F |St. Paul 116 F |Farmington 115 F  |Redwood Falls 115 F|Madelia  114 F|South of Red Wing 114 F|Minnesota Lake 114 F |Morton 114 F|Lakeville 113 F|Morristown 113 F|West of Clara City 113 F.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several surface observations across McLeod County measured heat indices over 105 degrees for several hours during the afternoon of Wednesday, July 20th, and again Thursday afternoon July 21st. Temperatures only managed to fall into the mid to upper 70s during the morning of July 21st, and rebounded into the 80s and 90s once again by the afternoon. The highest heat index value was 113 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure aloft set up across the Southern Plains and Lower Mississippi Valley resulting in hot daytime temperatures in the mid 90s to near 100 degrees. Dewpoint temperatures were in the middle 70s to upper 70s across the region as well...resulting in late morning and afternoon heat index values near or above 105 degrees.

A strong ridge of high pressure aloft anchored over the Southern Plains for several days in mid/late July. Temperatures during the afternoon hours climbed into the upper 90s to near 101 degrees, and combined with high humidity, this heat resulted in afternoon heat index values of 100 to 105 degrees across much of eastern Oklahoma, including Tulsa County. From the 18th through the 24th, at least eleven people were treated in Tulsa by medical personnel for heat-related illness. On the 19th, a heat-related fatality occurred in Tulsa County.

A prolonged period of hazardous heat and humidity occurred from July 18-24 in far western Kentucky from Princeton and Cadiz west. This is where heat indices peaked at or above 100 degrees for seven consecutive days. The peak heat index at the Paducah airport reached the following values: July 18 - 105 degrees, July 19 - 103 degrees, July 20 - 105 degrees, July 21 - 107 degrees, July 22 - 100 degrees, July 23 - 105 degrees, and July 24 - 105 degrees. Across the Pennyrile region of west Kentucky and the Henderson-Owensboro area, the duration of hazardous heat indices was shorter. For five consecutive days from July 21-25, heat indices peaked above 100 degrees. The heat index at Hopkinsville peaked between 102 and 105 each day. Local cooling centers were set up at churches or public buildings in a few cities, including Mayfield and Benton. State road maintenance crews adjusted their shift hours to avoid the hottest part of the afternoon. A weak surface high over the Tennessee Valley and southern Appalachians produced a light south wind flow of hot and humid air for an extended period.

A two year old girl died after being found in a vehicle in the Temple, TX area during the afternoon hours of July 10.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A two-year old girl was found inside a vehicle during the afternoon hours of July 10. Attempts to resuscitate her were unsuccessful and she was pronounced dead at Baylor Scott and White Memorial Hospital.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A two-year old boy died after being left in a hot car on Sunday afternoon July 24 in East Dallas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A two year old boy died after being left inside a hot car outside a church in East Dallas on the afternoon of Sunday, July 24.

For five consecutive days from July 21-25, heat indices peaked above 100 degrees. The heat index at Hopkinsville peaked between 102 and 105 each day. Local cooling centers were set up at churches or public buildings in a few cities, including Mayfield and Benton. State road maintenance crews adjusted their shift hours to avoid the hottest part of the afternoon. A weak surface high over the Tennessee Valley and southern Appalachians produced a light south wind flow of hot and humid air for an extended period.

Very hot and very humid weather, with daytime temperatures reaching the 90s, brought the heat index to 100 to 110 degrees during the afternoon hours of July 20th through July 22nd. Emergency rooms at hospitals reported that an unknown number of people suffered heat stress, heat exhaustion, or dehydration, although no lasting heat related illnesses were reported. Dew points in the 70s over the area reflected the very high humidity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reaching daytime highs in the 90s were accompanied by very humid conditions, with the heat index rising to 100 to 110 degrees. An unknown number of people suffered from heat stress, heat exhaustion, or dehydration, as reported by hospital emergency rooms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of hazardous heat and humidity occurred from July 18-24. Heat indices peaked near or above 100 degrees for seven consecutive days. The peak heat index at the Carbondale airport reached the following values: July 18 - 105 degrees, July 19 - 103 degrees, July 20 - 97 degrees, July 21 - 106 degrees, July 22 - 104 degrees, July 23 - 101 degrees, and July 24 - 103 degrees. A weak surface high over the Tennessee Valley and southern Appalachians produced a light south wind flow of hot and humid air for an extended period.

Very hot and very humid weather, with daytime temperatures reaching the 95 to 100 degree range, brought the heat index to 100 to 115 degrees during the afternoon hours of July 19th through July 23rd. Emergency rooms at hospitals reported that an unknown number of people suffered heat stress, heat exhaustion, or dehydration, although no lasting heat related illnesses were reported. Dew points in the 70s over the area reflected the very high humidity, with dew points at a few places peaking at or just above 80 degrees.

A prolonged period of hazardous heat and humidity occurred from July 18-24. Heat indices peaked near or above 100 degrees for seven consecutive days. The peak heat index at the Carbondale airport reached the following values: July 18 - 105 degrees, July 19 - 103 degrees, July 20 - 97 degrees, July 21 - 106 degrees, July 22 - 104 degrees, July 23 - 101 degrees, and July 24 - 103 degrees. A weak surface high over the Tennessee Valley and southern Appalachians produced a light south wind flow of hot and humid air for an extended period.

Strong high pressure over the southwestern continental United States brought triple digit heat to the central California region including the San Joaquin Valley and Kern County desert areas. Excessive heat was observed in parts of the Kern County desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mojave ASOS (KMHV) reported a high temperature of 108 degrees on 7/29.

Emergency rooms at hospitals reported that an unknown number of people suffered heat stress, heat exhaustion, or dehydration, although no lasting heat related illnesses were reported. Dew points in the 70s over the area reflected the very high humidity, with dew points at a few places peaking at or just above 80 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reaching daytime highs of 95 to 100 were accompanied by very humid conditions, with the heat index rising to 100 to 115 degrees. An unknown number of people suffered from heat stress, heat exhaustion, or dehydration, as reported by hospital emergency rooms.

A stretch of hot weather that began Friday, July 22 peaked on Monday, July 25, prompting Heat Advisories across much of central Pennsylvania and an Excessive Heat Warning across the Lower Susquehanna Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached between 105 and 110 degrees in York County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of hazardous heat and humidity occurred from July 18-24 in far western Kentucky from Princeton and Cadiz west. This is where heat indices peaked at or above 100 degrees for seven consecutive days. The peak heat index at the Paducah airport reached the following values: July 18 - 105 degrees, July 19 - 103 degrees, July 20 - 105 degrees, July 21 - 107 degrees, July 22 - 100 degrees, July 23 - 105 degrees, and July 24 - 105 degrees. Across the Pennyrile region of west Kentucky and the Henderson-Owensboro area, the duration of hazardous heat indices was shorter. For five consecutive days from July 21-25, heat indices peaked above 100 degrees. The heat index at Hopkinsville peaked between 102 and 105 each day. Local cooling centers were set up at churches or public buildings in a few cities, including Mayfield and Benton. State road maintenance crews adjusted their shift hours to avoid the hottest part of the afternoon. A weak surface high over the Tennessee Valley and southern Appalachians produced a light south wind flow of hot and humid air for an extended period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot and humid conditions persisted throughout the month of August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local newspapers report that a 31 year old man died due to hyperthermia in an automobile in Columbus. Temperatures reached into the middle 90s during the afternoon and the man was found in the front seat of his car with all of the windows rolled up.

The woman was found inside a car, with all of the windows rolled up, in the parking lot of the Midtown Medical Center in Columbus. Afternoon temperatures were in the mid to upper 90s in Columbus this day.

A two day period of heat and humidity affected northeast Iowa in the middle of July. Heat indices on the 21st and 22nd topped out between 105 and 115. The highest reported heat index was 120 from a mesonet reporting station in the Yellow River State Park (Allamakee County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices topped out between 105 and 115 on both the 21st and 22nd. The highest reported het index was 120 from a mesonet reporting station in the Yellow River State Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions became established across southern WI for several days. Maximum heat index values reach 95 degrees or warmer for the majority of this period. The WI Department of Health Services designated hundreds of cooling centers across  WI. In addition, the Milwaukee Health Department and the Housing Authority of the city of Milwaukee opened cooling stations. Hospitals reported 29 people in the Milwaukee area treated for heat related illness.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum heat index values ranged from 90 to 100 degrees through the period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and abnormally large upper level high pressure area along with high dew points brought high heat indices to central and northeast South Dakota. High temperatures were in the upper 80s to the 100s with overnight lows in the upper 60s to the mid 70s. A few of the highest heat index values include: 105 degrees at Britton, 106 degrees at Sisseton and Watertown, 107 degrees at Pierre, 108 degrees at Aberdeen and Clark, 109 degrees at Mobridge, 110 degrees at Eureka and Miller and 111 degrees at Clear Lake.

Hot temperatures and humid conditions resulted in 17 heat incidents during the PGA tournament in Springfield NJ.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The State Emergency Operations Center reported 17 heat related illnesses, due to heat exposure. This occurred during the PGA tournament at Baltrusrol Golf Club in Springfield NJ. Temperatures rose to the lower 90s in the afternoon. The combination of these temperatures and high humidity made it feel like the mid 90s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of hazardous heat and humidity occurred from July 18-24, resulting in one death. Near Poplar Bluff, a 23-year-old man died after overheating during a strenuous workday trimming trees. The man started his workday around 7 A.M. on July 22 and became overheated around 4:30 that afternoon. He was hospitalized with a core temperature of more than 108 degrees and died the following day. Heat indices peaked above 105 degrees for four consecutive days in parts of southeast Missouri, mainly south and west of Cape Girardeau. Heat indices in this same area peaked above 100 degrees for seven consecutive days. The peak heat index at the Poplar Bluff airport reached the following values: July 18 - 105 degrees, July 19 - 102 degrees, July 20 - 103 degrees, July 21 - 108 degrees, July 22 - 111 degrees, July 23 - 106 degrees, and July 24 - 105 degrees. From Cape Girardeau north, heat indices peaked above 100 degrees for seven consecutive days, but they seldom reached 105. The peak heat index at the Cape Girardeau airport reached the following values: July 18 - 104 degrees, July 19 - 103 degrees, July 20 - 102 degrees, July 21 - 106 degrees, July 22 - 103 degrees, July 23 - 102 degrees, and July 24 - 102 degrees. A weak surface high over the Tennessee Valley and southern Appalachians produced a light south wind flow of hot and humid air for an extended period.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices topped out between 105 and 115 on both the 21st and 22nd. The highest reported heat index was 116 from a mesonet reporting station near Riceville.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices topped out between 105 and 115 on both the 21st and 22nd. The highest reported heat index was 115 from a mesonet reporting station in Ossian while Decorah had a heat index of 109 on the 21st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions became established across southern WI for several days. Maximum heat index values reach 95 degrees or warmer for the majority of this period. The WI Department of Health Services designated hundreds of cooling centers across  WI. In addition, the Milwaukee Health Department and the Housing Authority of the city of Milwaukee opened cooling stations. Hospitals reported 29 people in the Milwaukee area treated for heat related illness.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum heat index values ranged from 90 to 100 degrees through the period.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum heat index values ranged from 90 to 100 degrees through the period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and abnormally large upper level high pressure area along with high dew points brought high heat indices to central and northeast South Dakota. High temperatures were in the upper 80s to the 100s with overnight lows in the upper 60s to the mid 70s. A few of the highest heat index values include: 105 degrees at Britton, 106 degrees at Sisseton and Watertown, 107 degrees at Pierre, 108 degrees at Aberdeen and Clark, 109 degrees at Mobridge, 110 degrees at Eureka and Miller and 111 degrees at Clear Lake.

A prolonged period of hazardous heat and humidity occurred from July 18-24, resulting in one death. Near Poplar Bluff, a 23-year-old man died after overheating during a strenuous workday trimming trees. The man started his workday around 7 A.M. on July 22 and became overheated around 4:30 that afternoon. He was hospitalized with a core temperature of more than 108 degrees and died the following day. Heat indices peaked above 105 degrees for four consecutive days in parts of southeast Missouri, mainly south and west of Cape Girardeau. Heat indices in this same area peaked above 100 degrees for seven consecutive days. The peak heat index at the Poplar Bluff airport reached the following values: July 18 - 105 degrees, July 19 - 102 degrees, July 20 - 103 degrees, July 21 - 108 degrees, July 22 - 111 degrees, July 23 - 106 degrees, and July 24 - 105 degrees. From Cape Girardeau north, heat indices peaked above 100 degrees for seven consecutive days, but they seldom reached 105. The peak heat index at the Cape Girardeau airport reached the following values: July 18 - 104 degrees, July 19 - 103 degrees, July 20 - 102 degrees, July 21 - 106 degrees, July 22 - 103 degrees, July 23 - 102 degrees, and July 24 - 102 degrees. A weak surface high over the Tennessee Valley and southern Appalachians produced a light south wind flow of hot and humid air for an extended period.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices topped out between 105 and 115 on both the 21st and 22nd. The highest reported heat index was 117 from a mesonet reporting station in Fayette.  Oelwein had a heat index of 113 on the 21st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A two day period of heat and humidity affected southeast Minnesota in the middle of July. Heat indices on the 21st and 22nd topped out between 105 and 115. The Rochester (Olmsted County) public schools canceled summer school classes on the 21st and a community parade was canceled on the 22nd because of the heat and humidity.  The highest reported heat index was 119 from mesonet reporting stations near Mound Prairie (Houston County) and north of Rochester.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices topped out between 105 and 115 on both the 21st and 22nd. The highest reported heat index was 119 by a mesonet reporting station near Mound Prairie.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A two day period of heat and humidity affected western Wisconsin in the middle of July. Heat indices on the 21st and 22nd topped out between 105 and 115. Around two dozen people utilized a cooling center opened by the Salvation Army in La Crosse (La Crosse County). The highest reported heat index was 127 from mesonet reporting station west of Gotham (Richland County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices topped out between 100 and 105 on both the 21st and 22nd. The highest reported heat index was 104 from a mesonet reporting station south of Arcadia.

The peak heat index at the Cape Girardeau airport reached the following values: July 18 - 104 degrees, July 19 - 103 degrees, July 20 - 102 degrees, July 21 - 106 degrees, July 22 - 103 degrees, July 23 - 102 degrees, and July 24 - 102 degrees. A weak surface high over the Tennessee Valley and southern Appalachians produced a light south wind flow of hot and humid air for an extended period.

A prolonged period of hazardous heat and humidity occurred from July 18-24, resulting in one death. Near Poplar Bluff, a 23-year-old man died after overheating during a strenuous workday trimming trees. The man started his workday around 7 A.M. on July 22 and became overheated around 4:30 that afternoon. He was hospitalized with a core temperature of more than 108 degrees and died the following day. Heat indices peaked above 105 degrees for four consecutive days in parts of southeast Missouri, mainly south and west of Cape Girardeau. Heat indices in this same area peaked above 100 degrees for seven consecutive days. The peak heat index at the Poplar Bluff airport reached the following values: July 18 - 105 degrees, July 19 - 102 degrees, July 20 - 103 degrees, July 21 - 108 degrees, July 22 - 111 degrees, July 23 - 106 degrees, and July 24 - 105 degrees. From Cape Girardeau north, heat indices peaked above 100 degrees for seven consecutive days, but they seldom reached 105. The peak heat index at the Cape Girardeau airport reached the following values: July 18 - 104 degrees, July 19 - 103 degrees, July 20 - 102 degrees, July 21 - 106 degrees, July 22 - 103 degrees, July 23 - 102 degrees, and July 24 - 102 degrees. A weak surface high over the Tennessee Valley and southern Appalachians produced a light south wind flow of hot and humid air for an extended period.

A two day period of heat and humidity affected western Wisconsin in the middle of July. Heat indices on the 21st and 22nd topped out between 105 and 115. Around two dozen people utilized a cooling center opened by the Salvation Army in La Crosse (La Crosse County). The highest reported heat index was 127 from mesonet reporting station west of Gotham (Richland County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices topped out between 105 and 115 on both the 21st and 22nd. The highest reported heat index was 117 from a mesonet reporting station in Readstown. Viroqua had a heat index of 105 on the 21st and 101 on the 22nd.

Around two dozen people utilized a cooling center opened by the Salvation Army in La Crosse (La Crosse County). The highest reported heat index was 127 from mesonet reporting station west of Gotham (Richland County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices topped out between 105 and 115 on both the 21st and 22nd. The highest reported heat index was 114 by a mesonet reporting station near Bangor. Around two dozen people used a cooling center in La Crosse opened by the Salvation Army.  At the La Crosse Airport (ASOS) the heat index reached 106 on the 21st and 105 on the 22nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and abnormally large upper level high pressure area along with high dew points brought high heat indices to central and northeast South Dakota. High temperatures were in the upper 80s to the 100s with overnight lows in the upper 60s to the mid 70s. A few of the highest heat index values include: 105 degrees at Britton, 106 degrees at Sisseton and Watertown, 107 degrees at Pierre, 108 degrees at Aberdeen and Clark, 109 degrees at Mobridge, 110 degrees at Eureka and Miller and 111 degrees at Clear Lake.

A strong ridge of high pressure aloft centered over Texas resulted in a period of unseasonably hot weather over the area in early July. Temperatures on the 6th climbed into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees, and combined with very high humidity, this heat resulted in afternoon heat index values of 110 to 115 degrees across portions of northeastern Oklahoma.

Hot and humid conditions became established across southern WI for several days. Maximum heat index values reach 95 degrees or warmer for the majority of this period. The WI Department of Health Services designated hundreds of cooling centers across  WI. In addition, the Milwaukee Health Department and the Housing Authority of the city of Milwaukee opened cooling stations. Hospitals reported 29 people in the Milwaukee area treated for heat related illness.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum heat index values ranged from 90 to 110 degrees through the period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions with high temperatures in the mid 90s and heat index values between 105 and 109 degrees resulted in a death in Chowan county in northeast North Carolina.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions with high temperatures in the mid 90s and heat index values between 105 and 109 degrees resulted in the death of a man in Chowan county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm period continued over southern WI. One heat-related death occurred in Milwaukee. Heat index values were in the lower 90s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One heat-related death occurred. Heat index values reached the lower 90s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: From Amarillo Global News, at 4:40 PM, park police responded to a call at the canyons Lighthouse Trail, where an unidentified 53-year-old woman was transported to the Mack Dick Group Pavilion with the assistance of Canyon and Randall County firefighters and Baptist St. Anthonys paramedics. From there, she was airlifted to Northwest Texas Hospital where she later died.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The canyon floor reached a high temperature of 108 degrees at 4:18 PM.
